comments.commentBody: This post brings back memories, not only of Morning in America, but of month after painful month before when Reagan exhorted the nation to "Stay the course!"  His advisers knew that the cyclical upturn following the dismal years would be exhilarating and their man would get the credit.  At about the same time it became conventional wisdom for all newly elected presidents to engineer a recession early in their first terms.  Bush-Cheney were almost guaranteed an early  recession  by the bursting of the dot-com bubble.  And Cheney, in particular, exploited the situation perfectly, doing a lot of bellyaching and reminding voters that the Bush administration had been handed a lousy economy.

No, it is the fear of being homeless. I haven't had a name to give for 'who to call in an emergency' for quite some time now. And in case you didn't realize it, one good fluke illness or accident can wipe out everything - even if you have insurance. If your bill runs up to $1M, which can happen (and will continue to happen under Obamacare, which does squat to control provider costs), very few people have $200,000 of liquidity to pay 20% of that (after deductible) - especially if your income has gone to cover living costs and sky-high premiums.

I have close female friends in similar positions and I think they fear *both* not having anyone to take care of you them*and* not having the resources -- especially the financial resources -- to take care of themselves.  And this despite the fact that these friends have been pretty independent and able to take care of themselves *and* have substantial financial resources.  For myself, it is the question "who to call in an emergency?" that is most worrisome.  A friend mentioned to me that he takes his cellphone into the bathroom with him when he takes a shower -- despite the concern about moisture damaging the phone -- because, after all, he lives alone: what would happen if he slipped in the shower and couldn't call 911?  After that I carrying my cellphone everywhere in the house with me ... Fortunately I have never had to use it, but one day I might.

I don't think it's the fear of being homeless - I think it's the fear of not having anybody care about you - or for you.   It is very disturbing to be filling out paperwork and when asked, "who to call in an emergency"  - you're not sure. If there is no husband or significant other there are parents that are too old,  siblings too self-involved, or friends that aren't that close.   That's when it's time to do something about that situation, or begin financial planning for health coverage and care down the road.
As another commenter has noted, this piece is not so much about actual homelessness as it is about the *fear* of it, particularly among women, and especially among those who are alone.

My father, a WWII veteran, who passed away, six months, ago, has what the British call "a good war." He survived but suffered a non combat related disability. The war nevertheless strained his marriage, economically and emotionally. My mother was distracted by the strain, by raising a small child, on her own, and by the threat of loss. The extract in the New Yorker made it plain that such familial difficulties are still part of going to war.

Thirty years on, my service brought back bad memories to my mother, which were ameliorated by my being assigned, far from Asia.
Every soldier is the son/daughter, husband/wife, father/mother of civilians wrapped in the soldiers' lives. In the absence of a draft, most Americans may be divorced from the realities of war. Even worse, the absence of a draft may make it easier for politicians to decide on the use of force.

Both my father and I were opposed to going to war in Iraq. My father complained how glibly President Bush sent young me to die, while I was unconvinced of any need to invade Iraq, in 2003. Two weeks, ago, I was astonished at how some seem to want a small military action, and still want one, even if it had a great chance of starting a truly regional conflict. I would be happy with a diplomatic solution that removed the threat of the further use of chemical weapons, without degrading Assad's military. Actively pursuing "regime change," in the Middle East has not proved a winning policy for the U.S.

So, yes... right!

PS: the book is the acclaimed Elementary Statistics by Mario Triola...

"one bad pitch doesn't make it ineffective." Here's the description of the NYT Gameview of Robertson's inning:
"D.Robertson pitching. Machado flied out to left fielder A.Soriano. C.Davis struck out. A.Jones singled to center. Markakis singled to left, A.Jones to second. Valencia homered to center on a 0-0 count, A.Jones scored, Markakis scored. Hardy doubled to left. Wieters struck out. "
Robertson got three outs, one of which recorded with Soriano jumping over the fence to bring back Manny Machado's long fly, and gave up four hits. So Robertson's ERA for the appearance was 27.00, his WHIP was 4.00, the opposing batting average against for the inning was .571, the opponent's slugging percentage was 1.143, and the opponent's OPS for the inning was 1.714. How many measures of ineffectiveness are necessary to convince you?

@Michaellira: Calm yourself down. Since Robertson blew a three run lead, none of the other pitchers are, under ANY circumstances, eligible for the win. Face it, this would not be an issue if the Orioles hadn't lit up the usually effective Robertson like a Roman Candle. Not only did he give up a three run home run after getting the first two batters out, but one of those batters, Manny Machado, had to be robbed of a home run by Alfonso Soriano jumping over the fence to catch his long, long fly ball. Had that gone over the fence, then the run that the Yankee$ scored in the top of the ninth merely would have tied the game, instead of putting the Yankee$ ahead, it would have tied the game, putting a save out of reach anyway. From two outs and nobody on with a three run lead to a tied game in four batters? Pretty brief and ineffective. War is an illness and so is the American belief that we can change things by punishing nations (Afghanistan,Iraq, Syria) or that we can change society by putting people in prison.

We wage far more wars than other developed countries.

And we put people in prison at 7 times the rate of France, 9 times the rate of Germany and more than 25 times the rate of India.

That too is an enormous loss of American lives and American treasure.

It is a sickness to think that we can always "make the world a better place" by "being nasty to the bad guys."

The desire to punish, to seek revenge is an old one. But somehow we as a nation have managed to glorify it.

When Bush II was president, he chose the unfortunate word 'crusade' when speaking about avenging what happened in our country on 9-11. Soon there were strange fictions being created, fictions about 'aluminum tubes' and 'mushroom clouds', fictions later refuted as lies.

Each administration seems to create its own 'spin', within the last couple of weeks, an editorial with wisdom and truth written by the president of Russia which brought change, yet to read comments on another Times article today, the heroes are Kerry and Obama, as if ... they were the only ones responsible for this shift in emphasis. A shift away from a 'not a pinprick' military strikes to a seeming (though hedged) commitment to negotiating a peaceful framework for resolution in Syria.

Prior to Obama changing course, it was not difficult to find words in the Times by this administration stating that this possible military intervention in Syria was to send a message in the Middle East (another!) that America means what it says, we honor our 'red lines' and Iran is on notice that we have this capability and may exercise it against them.

Young men and women die for these ambitions of state, our ever messianic state which deludes itself into thinking we will always change things in a positive way by force. And our military contractors will always prosper.

War is an illness. Too many are swept up in its supposed allure of victory. But really, isn't what most of us want is lasting peace?
